Helena Wu: Helena Wu is a postdoctoral fellow at the Institute of Asian and Oriental Studies of the University of Zurich. Her research areas include postcolonial transformation, national/global/local relations in East-Asian contexts. Her latest publications include a peer-reviewed article on the spectatorships of Ten Years (omnibus, 2015) and a book chapter on the globalization of Chinese martial arts cinema in Chinese Martial Arts and Media Culture. She is the guest editor of a recently published special issue about Hong Kong at Interventions: An International Journal of Postcolonial Studies. Her forthcoming book discusses the local relations in Hong Kong.

Notes: 3 “Chin Ching Kam Sau/ A Splendid Future” 前程錦ç¹¡ is a theme song performed by Roman Tam in Cantonese for the popular Japanese drama series Oretachi no Tabi (1975) that was imported to Hong Kong in 1976. The insertion of the song in this 2014-film generates not only a nostalgia for the past (by a song singing about the future), but also a postulation of a future with hope extended from the mainstream discourse (by the optimistic message sourced from the past). The grand opening of Ah Kam’s new business where an ensemble of stars was presented also poses an intertextual reference to another Lunar New Year classic All’s Well, Ends Well, a franchise best known for its 1992, 1993 and 1997 editions (where the actress Sandra Ng played a role in the first instalment debuted in 1992 and the first redux version released in 2009, with the latter being a Hong Kong-China coproduction).

summary: Ten Years and these texts overlap in their portrayal of a dystopian future: A Clockwise Orange depicts the authority’s infliction of physical and psychological violence through rehabilitation program and behaviour correction in Britain’s future; Pink Floyd: The Wall addresses the structural violence extended from different oppressive systems in the society; Ikigam imagines a future where citizens between the ages of 18 and 24 are randomly killed for the betterment of the society.
They can all be read as a footnote to Ten Years’ overall disavowal of forced nationalization and ideological indoctrination in translocal contexts.
The original lyrics are: 這香港已不是我的地頭/就當我在外地旅遊.

Introduction: Ten Years and these texts overlap in their portrayal of a dystopian future: A Clockwise Orange depicts the authority’s infliction of physical and psychological violence through rehabilitation program and behaviour correction in Britain’s future; Pink Floyd: The Wall addresses the structural violence extended from different oppressive systems in the society; Ikigam imagines a future where citizens between the ages of 18 and 24 are randomly killed for the betterment of the society.
Results: They can all be read as a footnote to Ten Years’ overall disavowal of forced nationalization and ideological indoctrination in translocal contexts.
Conclusion: The original lyrics are: 這香港已不是我的地頭/就當我在外地旅遊.
